Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).raw_text: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (recognition of fundamental parental rights)
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: - Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (recognition of fundamental parental rights)
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: Troxel squarely addresses and reaffirms that parents have a fundamental liberty interest under the Fourteenth Amendment in the care, custody, and control of their children. The plurality opinion, joined by concurrences, explicitly labels this parental interest as a fundamental right and uses that characterization as the constitutional basis for invalidating the Washington visitation statute as applied. Thus the case is properly cited for the recognition of fundamental parental rights.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The liberty interest at issue in this case—the interest of parents in the care, custody, and control of their children—is perhaps the oldest of the fundamental liberty interests recognized by this Court. … In light of this extensive precedent, it cannot now be doubted that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protects the fundamental right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children.” 530 U.S. at 65–66.
